revision.text:
'''Gus Hunt''' is an [[United States|American]] intelligence officer.<ref name="uva">[http://www2.commerce.virginia.edu/cmit/activities/HuntBio.htm University of Virginia biography]</ref><ref name="adceadc">[http://www.afceadc.org/events/bios-presentations/ira-gus-hunt-biography Armed Forces Communication & Electronics Association, Washington, DC Chapter]</ref> He serves as the Chief Technology Officer for the Chief Information Officer at the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA).<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/><ref name="fcw">Wyatt Kash, [http://fcw.com/articles/2010/09/27/feat-gus-hunt-cia-qanda.aspx CIA needs nimble tech to keep pace], ''[[Federal Computer Week]]'', September 23, 2010</ref><ref name="huffington">Matt Sledge, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/20/cia-gus-hunt-big-data_n_2917842.html CIA's Gus Hunt On Big Data: We 'Try To Collect Everything And Hang On To It Forever'], ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', 03/21/2013</ref>
==Biography== ===Early life=== Gus Hunt received a ME in Civil/Structural Engineering from [[Vanderbilt University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/>
===Career=== He started his career as a Aerospace Engineer in the private sector for seven years.<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/>
He joined the CIA in 1985.<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/> He served as Director of Architecture and Systems Engineering (ASE), Chair of the CIA Architecture Review Board and the Architecture and Systems Engineers Occupational Panel, and Chief of the CIO's Advanced Technology Group within the Directorate of Intelligence (DI).<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/> He also served as Chief of Research and Development for the [[Director of Central Intelligence]]'s (DCI) Crime and Narcotics Center and Deputy Chief of the Operations Support Group in the DCI’s Non‐Proliferation Center.<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/> He later served as Director of Applications Services for CIA.<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/> He now serves as Chief Technology Officer for the Chief Information Officer at the CIA.<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/><ref name="fcw"/>
According to ''[[The Epoch Times]]'', at the [[GigaOM|GigaOm]] Structure Data conference at the [[Chelsea Piers]] in March 2013, he confirmed a deal between the CIA and [[Amazon.com]] with regards to [[cloud computing]].<ref>James Grundvig, [http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/united-states/the-cia-bets-all-in-the-cloud-an-intelligent-move-366401.html The CIA Bets All in the Cloud, an ‘Intelligent’ Move], ''[[The Epoch Times]]'', March 21, 2013</ref>
===Personal life=== He is married, and has two grown children.<ref name="uva"/><ref name="adceadc"/>
